tn.text: Hoshea became the king of the northern kingdom of Israel.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Samaria was the capital city of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: He did not obey Yahweh's laws as given to Moses. "In the sight of" is metaphor for judgment or opinion. AT: "evil to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Hoshea became his servant and brought him tribute
tn.text: Hoshea did as the King of Assyria commanded and brought money to him so that the King would not destroy Israel.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"every year" (UDB)

tn.ref: shut him up and bound him in prison
tn.text: "put Hoshea in prison" (UDB)
put troops around the city in order to force it to surrender
The name "Israel" is metonymy for the people living there. AT: "took the Israelite people to Assyria" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are the names of locations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The narrative pauses to summarize Yahweh's judgment on Israel.
This refers to the capture of the Israelites by the Assyrians.
"Hand" is metonymy for control, authority or power. AT: "the control of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Walking" is metaphor for the ways or patterns of behavior people use in their lives. AT: "doing the activities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The narrative continues to summarize Yahweh's judgment on Israel.

tn.ref: on every high hill and under every green tree
tn.text: These are exaggerations to show that worship of false gods was widespread. AT: "on high hills and under green trees everywhere" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
The narrative continues to summarize Yahweh's judgment on Israel.

tn.ref: performed wicked things to provoke Yahweh to anger
tn.text: Possible ways to render this: 1) "did many wicked things that caused Yahweh to become angry" (UDB) or 2) "did many sinful things that made Yahweh angry"

tn.ref: about which Yahweh had said to them
tn.text: "about which Yahweh had warned them"
The narrative continues to summarize Yahweh's judgment on Israel.

tn.ref: Yahweh had testified ... by every prophet
tn.text: Yahweh spoke through the prophets.
"Stop doing the evil things you have been doing"

tn.ref: I sent to you by my servants the prophets
tn.text: The prophets were sent by Yahweh to remind the people of God's Laws and to obey them.
The summary of Yahweh's judgment on Israel continues.
They were unwilling to follow God's laws and rely on Yahweh as their God.
They refused to obey God's Laws.
They followed the practices of the people around them.
"not to copy"
The summary of Yahweh's judgment on Israel continues.
Cast metal figures are objects made by pouring melted metal into a form (or mold) to make a shape.
"sorcery" (UDB)

tn.ref: sold themselves to do that which was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: To "sell themselves" is a metaphor for committing completely to do that which was evil. AT: "committed themselves to do things that Yahweh said were evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: removed them out of his sight
tn.text: "Sight" is metonymy for being within the attention of Yahweh so he no longer cared for them. AT: "removed them from his attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The summary of Yahweh's judgment on Israel includes how Judah also fell into idolatry.
The location "Judah" is metonymy for the people that live there. AT: "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Yahweh punished the Israelites"

tn.ref: gave them into the hand of those who would take the possession as spoil
tn.text: "Hand" is metonymy for control, power or authority. AT: "handed them over to those who robbed them of their property" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: until he had cast them out of his sight
tn.text: "his sight" is metaphor for attention and caring. AT: "He got rid of them all" (UDB) or "until they were no longer in his presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The reason for Yahweh's judgment on Israel continues by relating the history behind it.
"He tore" is a metaphor for violent removal. AT: "Yahweh removed the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: from the royal line of David
tn.text: "from the rule of David's descendants" (UDB)

tn.ref: drove Israel away from following Yahweh
tn.text: "turned the people of Israel away from following Yahweh"

tn.ref: they did not depart from them
tn.text: "The Israelites did not stop committing these sins" or "They did not turn away from those sins" (UDB)

tn.ref: so Yahweh removed Israel from his sight
tn.text: "Sight" is a metaphor for attention and care. AT: "So Yahweh removed the people of Israel from his attention and care" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh's judgment continues against the new Assyrian inhabitants who practice their pagan religions.
These are places in the Assyrian empire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: It happened at the beginning of their residence there
tn.text: "When those people first lived there"

tn.ref: The nations that you have carried away and placed in the cities of Samaria
tn.text: "The people you have moved from other lands and sent to live in the cities of Samaria"

tn.ref: do not know the practices required by the god of the land
tn.text: "do not know how to worship the God that the Israelites worshiped in this land" (UDB)

tn.ref: Take one of the priests there whom you brought from there
tn.text: "Take a priest who came from Samaria back there,"
"and let the Samaritan priest teach the people who are living there now"

tn.ref: Succoth Benoth ... Nergal ... Ashima ... Nibhaz ... Tartak ... Adrammelech ... Anammelech
tn.text: These are the names of gods, both male and female. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: burned their children in the fire
tn.text: "sacrificed their own children" (UDB) or "burned their children in fire as an offering"
This refers to the pagan people that the king of Assyria moved into the cities of Samaria.

tn.ref: they persist in their old customs
tn.text: "they continue in the same habits as before."
The people were only interested in appeasing Yahweh. They were either not interested or not aware Yahweh was interested in a relationship with them.
The summary comes toward the end with an appeal to worship only Yahweh.

tn.ref: with great power and a raised arm
tn.text: The phrase "raised arm" is metonymy for displaying power and means basically the same thing as "great power." AT: "with very great power" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"obey them"
The summary now ends with an appeal to worship only Yahweh and a description of the sins of the people.
"Listen" is a metaphor for paying attention and act on the command. AT: "They did not obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These nations feared Yahweh only to the point of appeasing him the same way they treated their own gods.
"This day" is metonymy for the time period in which the writer lived. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
